hero.title: From complex processes to simple, working applications.
hero.description:
Hi, I’m Kostiantyn Palyvoda — a full-stack developer.

I build web applications that automate real business workflows.
I design and develop full-stack solutions for booking, payments,
internal tools, and integrations with external services.

feature.iDo: Turning business requirements into working systems
feature.myApproach: I work with companies through a structured approach — starting with analyzing existing workflows, designing the right system architecture, and then building, deploying, and maintaining reliable full-stack solutions.
feature.analyze: There is no universal solution for every problem. Before choosing technologies, I analyze business processes to identify what actually needs to be automated. This approach helps avoid unnecessary complexityand focus on efficient solutions that save time and effort.
feature.design: My design decisions are based on real constraints. I aim for architectures that are easy to understand, practical to use, and scalable without unnecessary complexity.
feature.build: I follow a “measure twice, build once” approach. Development is guided by testing, early validation, and attention to security, usability, and performance.

homeContent.nonTechDescription: I build fast, clear, and reliable web applications that help businesses work smoothly. My focus is simple: great user experience, predictable behaviour, and systems that are easy to maintain.
homeContent.noTechFrontSection: <0>I</0> care a lot about <1>how an application feels for real people</1>. Slow pages, confusing interfaces, aggressive pop-ups, and meaningless banners are not “marketing” — <2>they are friction</2>. I aim for <3>clean screens</3>, <4>clear actions</4>, and a user who always understands what is happening: loading states, progress, success messages, and errors that explain what to do next.
homeContent.backendPhilosophy: <0>On</0> the backend, I choose <1>the approach that best fits the job</1> — not what looks fancy. For larger, long-term systems, I rely on <2>proven solutions</2> suitable for corporate-level products. For smaller and faster projects, I deliver <3>lightweight, stable, and secure systems</3> quickly. I also believe modern products should be <4>accessible internationally</4>, so I build with <5>multilingual support</5> in mind from the start.
homeContent.noTechAISection: <0>If</0> a task can be solved effectively with AI, I help integrate it in a <1>practical and controlled way</1>. This can include <2>AI agents for quality assurance, basic customer interactions, data analysis, or internal support workflows</2>.
homeContent.serverOrientedSection: I design and build <0>server-oriented web applications</0> with a strong focus on <1>performance</1>, <2>security</2>, and <3>clear system boundaries</3>.
homeContent.ssrPreference: I avoid overloading the client with responsibilities that belong on the server. For this reason, I strongly prefer <0>server-side rendering (SSR)</0>, which provides faster initial load, improved security, and better SEO.
homeContent.frameworkChoice: My framework of choice is <0>React Router in a Remix-style architecture</0>. This approach significantly reduces the need for excessive <1>useEffect</1> and <2>useMemo</2>, making many typical React state management patterns unnecessary. As a result, applications become easier to reason about and maintain.
homeContent.serverRuntime: This setup allows security-sensitive operations to run on the server while staying within a single ecosystem. Regardless of the backend choice, I always operate with <0>a Node.js runtime available on the server side</0>.
homeContent.formsPreference: For forms, I prefer <0>react-hook-form</0>, focusing on minimal re-renders and early validation. Validating user input during interaction — not after submission — improves both performance and user experience.
homeContent.backendIntro: I work confidently with two backend approaches, choosing based on system scale and complexity. For enterprise-level systems with complex domain logic, I prefer <0>Django</0> for its maturity, stability, and rich ecosystem.
homeContent.backendProtocols: For internal client-facing services, I often use <0>GraphQL</0> and <1>WebSockets</1> to support live interactions. For external integrations and third-party systems, <2>REST APIs</2> remain the most practical choice.
homeContent.nodeStack: For simpler systems and faster delivery, my stack includes <0>Node.js with Express</0> and <1>Keystone</1> with GraphQL schemas. Combined with React Router v7, the entire application lives in <2>a single, cohesive ecosystem</2>, making it quick to launch and easy to maintain. Everything is built with <3>TypeScript</3>.
homeContent.testingMindset: I follow a <0>development driven by tests</0> mindset, validating assumptions early and reducing costly changes later.
homeContent.ciCdStack: For CI/CD, I prefer <0>GitHub Actions</0>. I have hands-on experience deploying and maintaining applications on <1>AWS</1>, <2>DigitalOcean</2>, and <3>Heroku</3>. Server configuration and reverse proxying are handled with <4>NGINX</4>.
homeContent.engineeringBackgroundIntro: I came to web development from <0>bot development and desktop applications</0>. I have experience building complex, multi-user bots for <1>Telegram, WhatsApp, and Viber</1>, as well as desktop applications using <2>PyQt6</2>.
homeContent.engineeringBackgroundWeb: In web development, I have extensive experience integrating <0>third-party APIs</0>, <1>payment systems</1>, and cloud services from <2>Microsoft</2> and <3>Google Cloud</3>.
homeContent.aiApproach: My approach focuses on <0>fast implementation</0>, <1>proper training</1>, and <2>fine-tuning to real business scenarios</2> — not experiments or buzzwords. AI is treated as a tool that <3>supports people and processes</3>, not replaces them blindly.

medicalBot.title: Medical Services Platform
medicalBot.problemDescription:
The client’s existing mobile application was underperforming.
Users were reluctant to install an app from the store, and the web version had a long and complex registration flow. A significant number of users dropped out midway and eventually chose to book appointments by calling the call center instead.
medicalBot.highLoad: High load on call center operators
medicalBot.solutionDescription: We proposed a messenger-first approach using a Telegram bot as the primary entry point for patients.The bot was designed to handle three core call center scenarios:
medicalBot.MVPDescription:
An MVP was launched within one week.
The results exceeded expectations:
medicalBot.LiCompletionRate: Significantly higher completion rate compared to the web app
medicalBot.LiCallCenter: Reduced pressure on call center staff
medicalBot.platformEvolutionDescription: After validating the initial concept, the platform was redesigned with a stronger emphasis on <0>security</0>, <1>usability</1>, and <2>scalability</2>.
medicalBot.platformImprovementUi: a more structured and user-friendly interface
medicalBot.platformImprovementCalendar: calendar-based appointment selection with real-time availability
medicalBot.platformImprovementCrm: deeper integration with the Doctor ELEKS CRM
medicalBot.platformResultPatientLookup: retrieve patient data by phone number
medicalBot.platformResultAvailability: check real-time availability of medical specialists
medicalBot.platformResultSelfService: enable self-service appointment booking and cancellation
medicalBot.platformResultTracking: allow patients to track test results, documents, and medical analyses
medicalBot.workflowDescription: Instead of building a separate operator dashboard at an early stage, we optimized existing workflows to reduce development overhead.
medicalBot.workflowRouting: all incoming requests were routed to private Telegram groups with operators
medicalBot.workflowStatuses: request statuses were tracked and updated directly within message threads
medicalBot.workflowVisibility: status changes were visible to both operators and patients
medicalBot.workflowOutcome: This approach kept operations <0>transparent and efficient</0> while significantly reducing implementation complexity and time to market.
medicalBot.telegramLimitsIntro: During real-world usage, we identified limitations of a pure messenger UI:
medicalBot.telegramLimitForms: limited flexibility for advanced filters and forms
medicalBot.webAppDescription: A full-featured web application running inside the messenger’s internal browser.
medicalBot.webAppTelegramAuth: Telegram used only for authentication and identity
medicalBot.webAppRichUi: Rich UI built with modern web frameworks
medicalBot.aiDescription: The bot is extended with an AI agent capable of conducting structured conversations with patients.
medicalBot.aiGuidance: Provide basic guidance and book appointments based on real availability
medicalBot.aiConversational: No UI required — fully conversational flow
medicalBot.operatorDescription: A dedicated interface for operators to manage incoming requests.
medicalBot.operatorDrafting: AI-powered assistance for draft responses and recommendations
medicalBot.operatorSeparation: Clear separation between human decisions and AI suggestions
medicalBot.roadmapClosing: The goal is not to replace medical professionals, but to <0>augment their work</0> with AI tools in a <1>controlled and transparent</1> way — especially critical in the medical domain.
medicalBot.valuePointEntry: messenger-based entry points can outperform traditional apps
medicalBot.valuePointAutomation: automation can reduce call center load without sacrificing control
medicalBot.valuePointAi: AI can enhance — not replace — human-driven medical workflows
medicalBot.valueAdaptIntro: The same architecture can be adapted for:

massageStudio.title: Massage Therapist Portfolio & Booking Website
massageStudio.message: Personal portfolio and flexible booking system for solo practitioners
massageStudio.problemIntro: The client is the owner of a hardware massage studio and approached me with a request to create a personal website that would present her as a professional, explain the massage technology, and help organize client bookings.
massageStudio.constraintText: Simplicity was critical. The client was not comfortable with complex tools or traditional booking systems. She preferred personal communication and was already used to chatting with clients via messengers such as <0>Telegram</0> and <1>WhatsApp</1>.
massageStudio.noClassicBooking: A classic booking system with fixed working hours and predefined availability slots was not suitable. The client did not operate on a strict schedule and preferred to adapt her availability individually for each client.
massageStudio.solutionIntro: We designed a personal portfolio website combined with a flexible, request-based booking flow.
massageStudio.storefrontIntro: Instead of enforcing a rigid calendar, the website works like a service-oriented storefront:
massageStudio.flowSubmitRequest: submit a booking request rather than an instant reservation
massageStudio.solutionOutcome: This approach preserved personal communication while removing manual routine from the process.
massageStudio.mvpIntro: The MVP included the following core features:
massageStudio.mvpFeatureBlog: A personal blog and portfolio presenting the therapist and the massage technology
massageStudio.mvpFeatureCatalog: A service catalog similar to an online store, where services replace products
massageStudio.mvpFeatureCart: A cart-based booking flow with service selection and a preferred time window
massageStudio.mvpFeatureNotifications: Automated notifications sent to the therapist via Telegram, WhatsApp, or other messengers
massageStudio.mvpPanelIntro: Each booking request included a link to a web-based request management panel that opened directly in the browser.
massageStudio.mvpPanelChat: the therapist could chat with the client in real time via a built-in web messenger
massageStudio.mvpPanelDelivery: messages were delivered instantly to the client, including email notifications with a link back to the conversation
massageStudio.mvpPanelClose: once confirmed, the therapist could assign a final appointment time and close the request
massageStudio.mvpClosingCalendar: created an event in Google Calendar
massageStudio.mvpClosingDb: stored the appointment in the application database
massageStudio.mvpSyncDelete: deleting an event in the calendar triggered an automatic cancellation notification to the client
massageStudio.mvpSyncCancel: bookings could also be canceled directly from the panel with one click, sending an automated message
massageStudio.mvpCheckout: During checkout, clients completed a short questionnaire with industry-standard questions and acknowledged service terms. This significantly reduced repetitive communication and preparation work for the therapist.
massageStudio.mvpSaasIntro: The MVP also included basic SaaS-style functionality:
massageStudio.mvpSaasPromos: creating promotional offers and bundled procedures
massageStudio.mvpLocalization: The application was localized into <0>four languages</0>, including AI-assisted translation of dynamic content.
massageStudio.mvpOutcome: Although the project has not yet been publicly launched, it resulted in a fully functional and reusable template for similar service-based businesses.
massageStudio.roadmapCalendar: an internal admin calendar to manage, reschedule, and cancel appointments
massageStudio.roadmapOperatorView: a unified operator view to quickly switch between active requests and client conversations
massageStudio.roadmapNavigation: improved navigation between booking requests and web messenger sessions
massageStudio.roadmapAutomation: further automation around reminders and follow-ups
massageStudio.roadmapOutcome: This roadmap focuses on preserving flexibility while improving operational visibility.
massageStudio.valueIntro: This project demonstrates how solo practitioners and small service businesses can:
massageStudio.valueFlexibleBooking: offer online booking without rigid schedules
massageStudio.valueReduceOverhead: reduce manual coordination and messaging overhead
massageStudio.valuePersonalTouch: keep personal communication while automating routine tasks
massageStudio.valueAvoidComplexity: avoid complex booking software that does not fit their workflow
massageStudio.valueAdaptIntro: The same architecture can be easily adapted for:
massageStudio.techRealtime: Realtime interaction: browser actions for live updates

transportOps.title: Passenger Transportation Management System
transportOps.problemIntro: A company operating in international passenger transportation approached me with a request to structure and automate their operations without significant upfront investment in a full-scale web platform, while keeping the system extensible for future growth.
transportOps.modelIntro: Their business model was non-standard. The company did not own its own bus fleet. Instead, it operated as a mediator between passengers and multiple transportation partners. Available routes were not fixed — they depended on real demand for specific directions.
transportOps.challengeNoTimetable: no classic timetable or predefined routes
transportOps.challengePlanning: difficulty planning trips based on incomplete demand
transportOps.challengeDecision: need to dynamically decide whether to operate a route internally or redirect passengers to partners
transportOps.solutionIntro: Instead of building a traditional booking website, we designed a request-driven operational system focused on internal automation and decision support.
transportOps.systemCollect: collect and aggregate passenger requests by direction
transportOps.systemDecide: decide whether a route should be executed or delegated to a partner
transportOps.systemFlexible: keep the process flexible without locking the business into rigid schedules
transportOps.closing: The emphasis was on internal tooling first, with a clear path toward a future web interface if needed.
transportOps.mvpIntro: The MVP focused on replacing manual coordination with a structured workflow.
transportOps.capabilityGrouping: grouping and prioritization by route and date
transportOps.capabilityDecision: internal decision points for route activation or partner redirection
transportOps.capabilityTracking: clear tracking of request status and outcomes
transportOps.resultDataDriven: make routing decisions based on data rather than intuition
transportOps.mvpOutcome: Most importantly, the system aligned with the company’s real business model instead of forcing a classic booking structure.
transportOps.roadmapIntro: Planned next steps for the platform include:
transportOps.roadmapWebIntake: a lightweight web interface for request intake
transportOps.roadmapPartnerSelection: automated partner selection based on availability and conditions
transportOps.roadmapTransition: gradual transition from internal tooling to customer-facing features
transportOps.roadmapOutcome: This staged approach keeps costs low while allowing the system to grow alongside the business.
transportOps.valueIntro: This project demonstrates how transportation and logistics companies can:
transportOps.valueAssets: build digital systems without owning physical assets
transportOps.valueDemand: operate effectively with request-based demand models
transportOps.valueScale: gradually scale from internal tools to customer-facing systems
transportOps.valueAdaptIntro: The same approach can be adapted for:
transportOps.techArchitecture: Architecture focus: internal-first, extensible by design
